metadata.Description: Well organized and easy to understand Web building tutorials with lots of examples of how to use HTML, CSS, JavaScript, SQL, Python, PHP, Bootstrap, Java, XML and more.
metadata.og:description: W3Schools offers free online tutorials, references and exercises in all the major languages of the web. Covering popular subjects like HTML, CSS, JavaScript, Python, SQL, Java, and many, many more.

content.text: C++ Sets
C++ Set
A set stores unique elements where they:
content.html: A set stores unique elements where they:

content.text: To use a set, you have to include the <set> header file:
content.html: To use a set, you have to include the <set> header file:

content.code_html:
// Include the set library
#include <set>

content.text: Create a Set
To create a set, use the set keyword, and specify the type of values it should store within angle brackets <> and then the name of the set, like: set < type > setName .
content.html: To create a set, use the set keyword, and specify the type of values it should store within angle brackets <> and then the name of the set, like: set<type> setName.

syntaxHighlighting.text:
// Create a set called cars that will store strings
  set<string> cars;
// Create a set called cars that will store strings

content.code:
// Create a set called cars that will store strings
set<string> cars;

syntax_highlighting.text:
// Create a set called cars that will store strings
  set<string> cars;
// Create a set called cars that will store strings

content.code_html:
// Create a set called cars that will store strings
 set<string> cars;

syntax_highlighting_data.text:
// Create a set called cars that will store strings
  set<string> cars;
// Create a set called cars that will store strings

content.text: If you want to add elements at the time of declaration, place them in a comma-separated list, inside curly braces {} :
content.html: If you want to add elements at the time of declaration, place them in a comma-separated list, inside curly braces {}:

syntaxHighlighting.text: // Create a set called cars that will store strings

syntax_highlighting.text: // Create a set called cars that will store strings

content.code_html:
// Create a set called cars that will store strings
 set<string> cars = {"Volvo", "BMW", "Ford", "Mazda"};

// Print set elements
 for (string car : cars) {
  cout << car << "\n";
}

syntax_highlighting_data.text: // Create a set called cars that will store strings

content.text: As you can see from the result above, the elements in the set are sorted automatically. In this case, alphabetically, as we are working with strings.
content.html: As you can see from the result above, the elements in the set are sorted automatically. In this case, alphabetically, as we are working with strings.

content.text: If you store integers in the set, the returned values are sorted numerically:
content.html: If you store integers in the set, the returned values are sorted numerically:

syntaxHighlighting.text:
// Create a set called 
  numbers that will store integers

syntax_highlighting.text:
// Create a set called 
  numbers that will store integers

content.code_html:
// Create a set called numbers that will store integers
 set<int> numbers = {1, 7, 3, 2, 5, 9};

// Print set elements
 for (int num : numbers) {
  cout << num << "\n";
}

syntax_highlighting_data.text:
// Create a set called 
  numbers that will store integers

content.text: Note: The type of the set (e.g. string and int in the examples above) cannot be changed after its been declared.
content.html: Note: The type of the set (e.g. string and int in the examples above) cannot be changed after its been declared.

content.text: Sort a Set in Descending Order
By default, the elements in a set are sorted in ascending order. If you want to reverse the order, you can use the greater < type > functor inside the angle brackets, like this:
content.html: By default, the elements in a set are sorted in ascending order. If you want to reverse the order, you can use the greater<type> functor inside the angle brackets, like this:

syntaxHighlighting.text: // Sort elements in a set in descending order

syntax_highlighting.text: // Sort elements in a set in descending order

content.code_html:
// Sort elements in a set in descending order
 set<int, greater<int>> numbers = {1, 7, 3, 2, 5, 9};
// Print the elements
 for (int num : numbers) {
  cout << num << "\n";
}

syntax_highlighting_data.text: // Sort elements in a set in descending order

content.text: Note: The type specified in greater < type > must match the type of elements in the set ( int in our example).
content.html: Note: The type specified in greater<type> must match the type of elements in the set (int in our example).

content.text: Unique Elements
Elements in a set are unique, which means they cannot be duplicated or equal.
content.html: Elements in a set are unique, which means they cannot be duplicated or equal.

content.text: For example, if we try to add "BMW" two times in the set, the duplicate element is ignored:
content.html: For example, if we try to add "BMW" two times in the set, the duplicate element is ignored:

content.code_html:
set<string> cars = {"Volvo", "BMW", "Ford", "BMW", "Mazda"};

// Print set elements
 for (string car : cars) {
  cout << car << "\n";
}

content.text: Add Elements
To add elements to a set, you can use the .insert() function:
content.html: To add elements to a set, you can use the .insert() function:

content.code_html:
set<string> cars = {"Volvo", "BMW", "Ford", "Mazda"};

// Add new elements
cars.insert("Tesla");
cars.insert("VW");
cars.insert("Toyota");
cars.insert("Audi");

content.text: Remove Elements
To remove specific elements from a set, you can use the .erase() function:
content.html: To remove specific elements from a set, you can use the .erase() function:

content.code_html:
set<string> cars = {"Volvo", "BMW", "Ford", "Mazda"};

// Remove elements
 cars.erase("Volvo");
cars.erase("Mazda");

content.text: To remove all elements from a set, you can use the .clear() function:
content.html: To remove all elements from a set, you can use the .clear() function:

content.code_html:
set<string> cars = {"Volvo", "BMW", "Ford", "Mazda"};

// Remove all elements
 cars.clear();

content.text: Find the Size of a Set
To find out how many elements a set has, use the .size() function:
content.html: To find out how many elements a set has, use the .size() function:

content.code_html:
set<string> cars = {"Volvo", "BMW", "Ford", "Mazda"};
cout << cars.size();  // Outputs 4

content.text: Check if a Set is Empty
Use the .empty() function to find out if a set is empty or not.
content.html: Use the .empty() function to find out if a set is empty or not.

content.text: The .empty() function returns 1 ( true ) if the set is empty and 0 ( false ) otherwise:
content.html: The .empty() function returns 1 (true) if the set is empty and 0 (false) otherwise:

syntaxHighlighting.text:
set<string> cars;cout << cars.empty();  
  // Outputs 1 (The set is empty)

content.code:
set<string> cars;cout << cars.empty();
// Outputs 1 (The set is empty)

syntax_highlighting.text:
set<string> cars;cout << cars.empty();  
 // Outputs 1 (The set is empty)

content.code_html:
set<string> cars;
cout << cars.empty();  // Outputs 1 (The set is empty)

syntax_highlighting_data.text:
set<string> cars;cout << cars.empty();  
  // Outputs 1 (The set is empty)

content.code_html:
set<string> cars = {"Volvo", "BMW", "Ford", "Mazda"};
cout << cars.empty();  // Outputs 0 (not empty)

content.text: Loop Through a Set
You can loop through a set with the for-each loop :
content.html: You can loop through a set with the for-each loop:

syntaxHighlighting.text:
set<string> cars = {"Volvo", "BMW", "Ford", "Mazda"};
  for (string car : cars) {  cout << car << "\n";}

content.code:
set<string> cars = {"Volvo", "BMW", "Ford", "Mazda"};
for (string car : cars) {  cout << car << "\n";}

syntax_highlighting.text:
set<string> cars = {"Volvo", "BMW", "Ford", "Mazda"};
 for (string car : cars) {  cout << car << "\n";}

content.code_html:
set<string> cars = {"Volvo", "BMW", "Ford", "Mazda"};

for (string car : cars) {
  cout << car << "\n";
}

syntax_highlighting_data.text:
set<string> cars = {"Volvo", "BMW", "Ford", "Mazda"};
  for (string car : cars) {  cout << car << "\n";}

content.text: Tip: It is also possible to loop through sets with an iterator , which you will learn more about in a later chapter.
content.html: Tip: It is also possible to loop through sets with an iterator, which you will learn more about in a later chapter.

Which header file is required to use sets in C++?
content.html: Which header file is required to use sets in C++?
